The rising cost of prescription drugs has forced too many families to choose between maintaining their health and going into debt. 

President Trump promised to do something about it. At this point, you can probably guess what happened. https://t.co/uIA7goWzqA https://t.co/O8uW5UdSA8

Americans are paying too much for prescription drugs. 

For some brand-name drugs, U.S. prices are 10 times higher than other countries. 

We can’t allow drug companies to keep writing their own rules.

Here's my plan to help reduce America’s drug prices: https://t.co/D5rJQ9jMsx

The first thing we’ll do to bring down prescription drug prices is to do it the way other countries do it: through negotiation. We’ll revise the law to authorize Medicare to negotiate with drug companies, and set an upper limit for the negotiated price. https://t.co/BNROrR7B4L

We’ll ensure that insurers provide affordable prescription options. We’ll push for Medicare to review insurers’ lists of drugs that can be prescribed to ensure they promote the most cost-effective drugs, including generics. https://t.co/kkkqAWDZme

We’ll keep drug spending in check by capping Medicare beneficiaries’ out-of-pocket drug spending at $2,000 annually. We’ll also redesign the benefit to make insurers and drug companies shoulder more of the cost. https://t.co/kkkqAWDZme

We’ll force drug companies to function like any other market and compete on the price and value of their medicines, rather than the amount of money they pay for preferential treatment. We’ll do away with all drug-company payments to pharmacy benefit managers.

Part of how drug companies keep prices high is through layering on extra patents. We’ll limit each new drug to a single patent lasting 20 years and work with Congress to stop brand-name drug makers from slowing the introduction of generics.

Finally, we’ll leverage the federal government’s investments in drug research. 1 in 4 new drugs are rooted in this publicly supported research. When this research is sold to drug developers, we'll mandate that any resulting drug will be given a “value-based” price.

David Dinkins’s groundbreaking mayoral victory in 1989 helped New York City turn an important corner in racial equality.
He entered City Hall at a difficult time in New York’s history, and he helped set the city on a course for success – and a reduction in crime – that no one at the time imagined possible.
He was always generous to me during my time in office, for which I was grateful -- and I took every opportunity to remind people that mayors after him stood on his shoulders and built on his legacy.

Today, while others may remember his distinguished and courtly demeanor, I will always remember a man, a Marine, a mayor and a friend who was deeply proud of his service to his city and country – and rightly so.

Today, @BloombergDotOrg is convening 38 mayors from around the world for the fifth Bloomberg Harvard City Leadership Initiative (@BHCityMayors). 

Some advice I shared with the mayors:

Have a team that isn’t afraid to speak their minds. 

You don’t have to agree with them – but being able to hear hard truths from your team is essential.

Don’t be afraid to ask the basic questions. 

I can’t tell you how many times I’ve asked a basic question to someone giving a presentation – and they don’t know the answer.

Leadership is a constant learning experience.
